questions.q: Explain outsourcing as a source of software. Discuss its advantages, disadvantages, and when it is appropriate to use it.
options: Outsourcing involves hiring a third-party vendor to develop or manage software instead of doing it internally.
questions.explanation:
Advantages: Provides access to specialized skills not available in-house, can be cost-effective for one-off projects, and frees up internal staff to focus on core business operations.

Disadvantages: Results in a loss of direct control over the development timeline, introduces potential security/confidentiality risks, and creates reliance on an external vendor.

When to use: It is best used when an organization lacks internal technical expertise, when the project is not a core competency of the business, or when time-to-market is critical and requires extra manpower.

questions.q: Describe the six sources of software available to organizations with examples.
options: `Organizations can source software through IT Services Firms (Outsourcing), Packaged Software Providers, ERP Providers, Cloud Computing, Open-Source Software, or In-House Development.`
questions.explanation:
IT Services/Outsourcing: Hiring a firm to build custom software (e.g., hiring Accenture).

Packaged Software: Buying pre-built, off-the-shelf software (e.g., Microsoft Office, Adobe Acrobat).

ERP Systems: Large-scale systems that integrate all business functions (e.g., SAP, Oracle ERP).

Cloud Computing (SaaS): Software hosted online and accessed via a browser (e.g., Google Workspace, Salesforce).

Open-Source Software: Software with freely available source code maintained by a community (e.g., Linux, MySQL).

In-House Development: Using internal staff to build software from scratch tailored specifically to the company's needs.

questions.explanation:
Advantages: They eliminate data silos, streamline communication between departments (like HR, Finance, and Supply Chain), and provide a single source of truth for business data.

questions.q: Explain cloud computing as a source of software and describe its main characteristics.
options: Cloud computing (specifically SaaS) delivers software applications over the internet, hosted on remote servers managed by a third-party provider.
questions.explanation: Explanation: Its main characteristics include accessibility from anywhere with an internet connection, no need for local installation or internal hardware infrastructure, automatic updates handled by the vendor, and a subscription-based pricing model. It allows companies to scale their software usage up or down quickly based on demand.

questions.q: Discuss how organizations evaluate off-the-shelf software before purchasing it.
options: Organizations evaluate off-the-shelf software by assessing cost, functionality, vendor viability, vendor support, flexibility, and documentation.
questions.explanation: Before buying, an organization must ensure the software's features match their needs (functionality) while offering the ability to adapt (flexibility). They must consider the Total Cost of Ownership (cost) and ensure the vendor is financially stable enough (viability) to provide long-term updates and help (vendor support). Finally, they check for adequate training materials (documentation) and how difficult the software is to deploy (ease of installation).
